acquired. Any lands so acquired shall thereafter be exempt from taxation, and
the City Council may pay and discharge any assessments against the lands for
the improvement of streets or the construction of sewers.
   C.   The City Council shall provide for the grading, fencing, ornamenting
and improving of all burial and cemetery grounds owned by the City and the
avenues leading thereto, and may construct walks and plant and protect
ornamental trees and shrubs therein, and provide for paying the cost thereof.
(1987 Code § 11-311)
7-5B-3: BURIAL LOTS:
   A.   Conveyance Of Lots; Abandoned Lots:
      1.   Lots in the cemetery shall be conveyed by certificate signed by the
Mayor and countersigned by the Clerk, under the Seal of the City.
      2.   The certificate shall show the price for which the lots are sold and
specify that the person to whom it is issued is the owner of the lot or lots
described therein by number, as laid down in the plat, for the purpose of
interment.
      3.   The certificate shall vest in the purchaser and his heirs a right to
the lot or lots, for the sole purpose of interment under the regulations of the
city council or board of cemetery trustees.
      4.   The certificate shall be entitled to record in the office of the
county clerk of the county in which the lot is situated without further
acknowledgment, and the description of lots by number shall be sufficient for
the purpose of record.
      5.   All abandoned lots or spaces of lots shall revert to the city. (1987
Code § 11-312)
   B.   Conveyance Or Devise Of Lot Held In Trust:
      1.   Any burial lot in the cemetery owned by the city may be conveyed or
devised by the owner back to, and held by, the city in perpetual trust for the
purpose of its preservation as a place of burial.
      2.   The lot so conveyed shall thereafter remain forever inalienable by
act of the parties, but the right to use the same as a place of burial of the
dead of the family of the owner and his descendants from generation to
generation shall remain, unless the deed of conveyance in trust shall provide
that interments in such lot shall be confined to the bodies of specified
persons, in which case the lot shall be forever preserved as the burial place
of the persons specified in the deed and shall never be used for any other
purpose whatever. However, no conveyance in trust shall be made without the
consent of the city council or board of cemetery trustees of the city. (1987
Code § 11-313)
   C.   Rules And Regulations Furnished To Lot Purchasers: The rules and
regulations governing the city cemetery shall be a part of each and every deed
for any lot in the cemetery and the city clerk shall make available to the
purchaser of each lot a copy of these rules and regulations upon request, and
the cemetery board and the city reserve the right and the power and authority
to change or alter any of the rules hereinafter set out, and to add additional
rules. (1987 Code § 11-315)
   D.   Lots Divided As Shown By Plat: No lot, parcel, or part of any of the
land constituting the cemetery shall be divided into parcels or subdivisions,
except as shown by the plat of the cemetery on file in the office of the county
clerk. (1987 Code § 11-317)
   E.   Prices Of Lots: Prices for cemetery lots will be as set by the city
council by motion or resolution. (1987 Code § 11-339)
   F.   Time Of Payment: All purchases for lots may be for a full lot, or any
number of spaces. Single spaces will be provided in the cemetery. All lots must
be paid in full at time of purchase. (1987 Code § 11-327)
   G.   Issuance Of Deeds: The city will issue a deed for all lots purchased.
(1987 Code § 11-318)
   H.   Lot Improvements; Deed Required: No improvements shall be made on any
lot or burial space until a deed has been issued and delivered. (1987 Code §
11-319)
   I.   Death Of Owner; Heirs Recognized: In the event the owner of a lot dies
intestate, his or her heirs, according to the laws of the state, shall be
recognized as the owner or owners of the lot. (1987 Code § 11-333)
   J.   Limitation On Family Purchases: No individual family shall be permitted
to buy more lots than for their family use. (1987 Code § 11-334)
7-5B-4: INTERMENT OF ALL RACES AND FAITHS:
The cemetery shall be maintained for interment of all races and faiths. (1987
Code § 11-329)
7-5B-5: DISINTERMENTS; CITY COUNCIL APPROVAL:
No disinterment will be allowed without the consideration and approval of the
city council, cemetery board, and properly filed papers through the state
department of health. (1987 Code § 11-335)
7-5B-6: REMOVAL OF UNKNOWN REMAINS TO OTHER GRAVESITES:
When the bodily remains of an unknown person are discovered in an unidentified
and unmarked grave of the city cemetery, the remains may be removed to some
other gravesite within the cemetery, at the expense of the city, if no record
exists as to a sale or conveyance of the lot and the city is without knowledge
that a body had been buried in the gravesite, in the event the lot is sold to
another person. An application for approval of the disinterment and removal of
the bodily remains shall be first filed with, and approval obtained from, the
State Health Department. (1987 Code § 11-307)
7-5B-7: HOURS ESTABLISHED:
   A.   Admission: Hours of admission to the cemetery shall be from official
sunrise until sunset. The cemetery shall be closed at all other times. This
rule may be altered to fill the needs of any emergency that shall arise, due to
a late interment, or to strengthen the rule to avoid vandalism. In this event,
a lock will be placed on the gates at nine o'clock (9:00) P.M., and the Police
Chief, Mayor, and City Clerk will retain a key. (1987 Code § 11-316)
   B.   Interments: All interments must be made between official sunrise until
sunset, excepting in the case of emergency, then only with permission of the
City Council or a certificate of the County Health Officer. (1987 Code § 11-
321; amd. 2004 Code)
7-5B-8: CEMETERY RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   Cemetery Plot, Lot And Right Of Interment:
      1.   Persons desiring to purchase a deed or plot, known as the right of
interment privilege must be issued a certificate upon payment for the burial
plot. The City Clerk will issue the deed along with the Cemetery Rules and
Regulations.
      2.   The deed will be signed and approved by City Manager or Mayor and
attested by City Clerk.
      3.   The lot will not be used for any other purpose other than the burial
of human remains or cremains.
      4.   The Cemetery Board does not require a vault to surround a casket.
      5.   The City requires 48-hour notice to mark a burial plot for a funeral
or placement of a monument, unless sooner interment is required by law or
religion.
      6.   Temporary markers are required for each burial to be placed at the
west end of the grave and can be purchased from the funeral home making burial
arrangements.
      7.   There is a limit of eight (8) cremains per grave.
      8.   Burials of remains shall be under the supervision of a licensed
funeral home. Burial of cremains may be performed without the supervision of a
licensed funeral home with prior notice and approval of the City.
      9.   All burials, except cremains, must be directed by the funeral home
of choice by the family.
      10.   No more than two (2) casket burials are allowed per lot. If stacked
burial is desired, then an outer burial container is required for the first
interment.
      11.   No burial or interment will be performed until all administrative
fees have been paid in full.
      12.   No for sale signs will be allowed on any lot. If a family wishes to
sell their lot, they must contact the City Clerk to advise of their wishes, and
the City can mark the lot on their map for sale.
      13.   If a family wishes to transfer a lot to another individual, they
must contact the City Clerk to make the appropriate transfer papers. All money
transferred will be between the individual families.
      14.   The funeral home is responsible for opening and closing the plot.
      15.   Burial measurements:
Distance between graves on walkway              6 feet
Distance between graves                         3 feet
Road width                                      12 feet
Street width                                    60 feet
Head is placed facing east                       
Monument is placed on the west end, facing east  
Grave width                                     5 feet
Grave length                                    10 feet
 
      16.   Plot cost four hundred dollars ($400.00), or as established by
motion or resolution of the City Council from time to time - twenty five
percent (25%) to Cemetery Fund; seventy five percent (75%) to City Maintenance
Fund.
   B.   Monuments, Markers And Benches:
      1.   Construction: Base and type:
         a.   All monuments or grave markers placed in the cemetery must either
be granite, marble or standard bronze.
         b.   All markers and monuments must be placed on a standard base
(concrete or marble pad) of such strength as to support the weight.
         c.   All monuments must have a thirty six inch (36") base and six inch
(6") apron, flush with the ground.
         d.   Aprons will be required on all sides for easy care, weed eating,
or mowing.
         e.   Benches must be installed on concrete pads no smaller than the
bench seat size.
         f.   Benches must be made entirely of granite.
         g.   Exceptions: VA upright monuments provided by the VA.
         h.   Exceptions: VA flat markers which are installed flush with the
existing surface level.
         i.   All monuments, benches and markers must be installed by the
contracted monument installers.
         j.   Any monument company setting a monument will be responsible for
the construction of such base or foundation and will reconstruct such base if
the monument or marker tilts or gives way at no cost to the City or the
purchaser.
         k.   Failure to notify the cemetery of any monument, bench or marker
installation, and not paying the setting fee, will result in the removal of the
marker, bench, or monument and not be re- installed until the fee is paid.
      2.   Height Limitation:
         a.   No monument or marker shall be erected on any lot or space that
exceeds five feet (5') in height, including any portion of the base extending
above the natural level of the ground.
         b.   Tombstones will be set parallel to walkways.
      3.   Setting Location:
         a.   All markers and monuments will be set according to the plans set
forth in this section.
         b.   All markers, benches, and monuments are to be installed on the
west end of the lot.
         c.   Veterans flat markers may be installed flush with the existing
surface level on the east end of the lot if another marker, bench, or monument
already exists on the west end.
         d.   All benches must be installed on the west end of the lot and
installed parallel with all other markers and monuments.
   C.   Fencing: No fencing or enclosing of the City or any authorized lots.
      1.   No lot, part, or parcel of the cemetery shall be enclosed by any
fence.
      2.   No curbing or coping will be allowed around a lot.
      3.   No gravel allowed on or around grave site.
      4.   No hedge or shrubs are allowed.
      5.   No trees or vines are allowed.
      6.   No other obstruction or structure will be allowed unless approved by
the Cemetery Board.
      7.   The City, acting by and through its Cemetery Board, reserves the
right to tear down and remove from the cemetery anything placed on the lots in
violation of this section.
   D.   Mausoleums Or Crypts: Mausoleums or crypts (above ground) are
prohibited.
      1.   All burials will be under ground.
   E.   Fee: Administrative fee for all installations will be two hundred
dollars ($200.00), or as established by motion or resolution of the City
Council from time to time.
   F.   Sidewalks And Walkways:
      1.   No walkways are allowed between graves.
   G.   Maintenance Of Cemetery Grounds:
      1.   The City is not responsible for any damage to monuments or markers
which may occur in normal upkeep of the cemetery.
      2.   All graves will be leveled flush with the ground and no mounds will
be permitted after natural settling has occurred.
      3.   The City will see that all graves that have sunken, are filled and
properly maintained.
      4.   The City or any of its authorized agents grant the authority to
plant trees or shrubbery and reserves and retains the right to prune or cut
back any such tree or shrub as deemed necessary, without permission of the
owner of the lot.
      5.   All obnoxious weeds and grasses will be kept from the confines of
the cemetery.
      6.   Any discolored, dilapidated, unsightly, or dangerous items to
visitors or that interfere with mowing will be removed and discarded and are
not the responsibility of the City.
   H.   Floral Arrangements:
      1.   The City reserves and retains the authority and power to remove from
any and all graves all floral designs and flower pieces when they become wilted
and unsightly in the sole judgment of the City or its authorized agents and
employees.
      2.   All artificial designs will be left until such time as they are
gathered by family or come apart.
      3.   In no case shall the City or the members of the Cemetery Board be
responsible for any such article removed.
      4.   All floral arrangements must be confined to permanently mounted
granite or marble vases.
      5.   Any decorations must be affixed to a monument, bench, or marker.
      6.   Those items affixed or that are placed on the contract pad will be
removed.
      7.   No shepherd's hooks or hanging baskets will be allowed.
      8.   Flags may be placed on gravesites during holidays and special
occasions.
      9.   Holiday grave blankets will be allowed from December 1 - 31,
Memorial Day florals from June 10 - 12th.
   I.   Rules Of Cemetery:
      1.   Gates will be open at sunrise and locked at sunset.
      2.   The cemetery will be locked on October 31st.
      3.   Hours of cemetery management will be Monday - Friday, eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M. to five o'clock (5:00) P.M.
      4.   If an emergency arises, please call the Police Department or 911.
      5.   Employees and contractors/vendors are not permitted to perform any
work for the burial except as requested by the City Manager.
      6.   Persons visiting the cemetery shall use only the roads and avenues
for vehicles.
      7.   Parking for overflow during funerals may be made outside the
cemetery front gate along the road.
      8.   Any persons conducting themselves in a disorderly manner will be
removed.
      9.   No profanity will be allowed at any time.
      10.   All persons within the boundaries of the cemetery shall avoid any
conduct unbecoming of a sacred place.
      11.   No persons shall be allowed to enter the cemetery while
intoxicated.
      12.   No alcohol is allowed on cemetery or City property.
      13.   Children under the age of twelve (12) must be accompanied by an
adult or guardian. Children may not be left unattended.
      14.   No climbing on monuments, walls, or trees.
      15.   Littering is prohibited.
      16.   No pets are allowed in the cemetery grounds with the exception of
service dogs.
   J.   Penalty:
      1.   Any person who violates any provision of this section, performs any
unlawful act as defined in this article, fails to perform any act required is
guilty of an offense and shall be issued a citation and pay a fine. Such
punishment shall be in addition to any other remedy available to the City with
reference to violations. (Ord. 2018-09, 7-26-2018)
7-5B-9: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or performs any unlawful
act as defined in this chapter, or fails to perform any act required in this
chapter, is guilty of an offense, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. Such punishment shall be in addition to any other remedy
available to the City with reference to violations of any portion of this
chapter. (1987 Code § 11-340)
CHAPTER 6
RAILROADS
SECTION:
7-6-1: Improvement Of Streets And Alleys
7-6-2: Sidewalk Construction And Maintenance
7-6-3: Climbing On Trains
7-6-1: IMPROVEMENT OF STREETS AND ALLEYS:
   A.   Tracks Within Or Adjacent To Streets: When a railway occupies any
portion of a street with its tracks running in a general direction of such
street, either on or adjacent thereto, the railway company shall improve the
space between its tracks and two feet (2') on either side thereof in the same
manner that the remainder of the street is to be, or has been, improved, or
with such other satisfactory material as the city council, by motion or
resolution, may approve.
   B.   Tracks Within Or Adjacent To Alleys: In case any railway company shall
occupy an alley with its track or tracks, such company shall improve, gutter,
drain, and grade such alley, and shall surface or pave it with the same
material which is to be, or has been, used on the alley, or with such other
satisfactory material as the city council, by motion or resolution, may
approve.
   C.   Crossing Streets:
      1.   When the tracks of any railroad company cross any street that is
being or has been paved, the company shall pave as much of the street as is
occupied by its track or tracks and two feet (2') on each side, using the same
material as is to be, or has been, used on the street, or such other
satisfactory material as the city council, by motion or resolution, may
approve.
      2.   When more than one track crosses a street within a distance of one
hundred feet (100'), measuring from inside rail to inside rail, the railroad
company shall grade, gutter, drain, and curb the street area between its
tracks, and surface or pave it with the same material which the city is to use,
or has used, on the street.
   D.   Maintenance: Railroad companies shall keep all such improvements made
by them in a good state of repair at all times. (1987 Code § 16-101; amd. 2004
Code)
7-6-2: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE:
Railway companies shall construct sidewalks crossing their rights of way, using
the same material as is used in adjacent sidewalks insofar as this is
practicable under the circumstances. They shall construct sidewalks on both
sides of the streets when both sides are used by pedestrians. The company shall
keep such sidewalks in a good state of repair at all times. (1987 Code § 16-
102)
7-6-3: CLIMBING ON TRAINS:
It is unlawful for any person to climb upon, hold to, or in any manner attach
himself to, any railway train, locomotive, or railway car, while such is in
motion within the city, unless such person is acting in line of duty, or to
board any train or railroad car, including a passenger, freight, or other car,
except with a proper ticket or the permission of the person in charge of the
train or car or in line of duty. (1987 Code § 16-103)
CHAPTER 7
CABLE TELEVISION SERVICE
SECTION:
7-7-1: Short Title
7-7-2: Definitions
7-7-3: Granting Of Permit
7-7-4: Term
7-7-5: Use Of Streets And Dedicated Easements
7-7-6: Maintenance Of System
7-7-7: Service
7-7-8: Insurance/Indemnity
7-7-9: Cancellation And Expiration
7-7-10: Enforcement Of Terms And Conditions
7-7-11: Equal Protection
7-7-12: Notices, Miscellaneous
7-7-13: Payment To City
7-7-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the McLOUD CABLE TELEVISION
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 2004-15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
BASIC SERVICE: Those audio and visual signals carried on the service tier of
the cable system which includes local off air television signals. Basic service
shall not include any other tier of service or any premium or pay per view
channels or services.
CABLE ACT: The cable communications policy act of 1984, PL 98-549, 47 USC
section 521 supp., as it may be amended or superseded.
CABLE SERVICE: A. The one-way transmission to subscribers of: 1) video
programming, or 2) other programming service, and
   B.   Subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection or
use of such video programming or other programming service.
CABLE SYSTEM OR SYSTEM: A system of antennas, cables, wires, lines, towers,
microwaves, waveguides, laser beams or any other conductors, converters,
equipment or facilities designed, constructed, or operated for the purpose of
producing, receiving, amplifying, modifying and distributing audio, video, and
other forms of communication or electronic signals for the purpose of providing
cable services to and from residential and business subscribers and locations
within the jurisdictional limits of the grantor.
CITY COUNCIL: The governing body of the grantor.
GRANTEE: Falcon Cable Media, a California limited partnership DBA Charter
Communications, and its permitted successors and assigns.
GRANTOR: The city of McLoud, Oklahoma.
GROSS REVENUES: Any revenue received by the grantee from the operation of the
cable system to provide cable services within the jurisdictional boundaries of
the grantor, provided, however, that such phrase shall not include any taxes,
fee or assessment of general applicability collected by the grantee from
subscribers for pass through to a government agency, including the FCC user
fee, franchise fees or unrecovered bad debt.
PERMIT: The authorization granted hereunder of a franchise, privilege, permit,
license or otherwise to construct, operate and maintain a cable system within
the jurisdictional limits of the grantor.
SCHOOL: At any educational level operated within the city by any accredited
public, private or parochial school system, but limited to elementary, junior
high school, and high school (K-12).
STREETS AND DEDICATED EASEMENTS: The public streets, avenues, highways,
boulevards, concourses, driveways, bridges, tunnels, parks, parkways,
waterways, alleys, all other rights of way and easements, and the public
grounds, places or water within the jurisdictional boundaries of grantor.
SUBSCRIBER: A lawful purchaser of any cable service delivered over the cable
system. (Ord. 2004-15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-3: GRANTING OF PERMIT:
The grantor hereby grants to grantee a nonexclusive permit for the use of the
streets and dedicated easements within the grantor for the construction,
operation and maintenance of the cable system, upon the terms and conditions
set forth herein. (Ord. 2004-15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-4: TERM:
The permit shall be for a term of fifteen (15) years, commencing sixty (60)
days after adoption of the ordinance codified herein by the city council.
Subsequent renewals shall be pursuant to the renewal provisions of the cable
act as it shall provide. (Ord. 2004-15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-5: USE OF STREETS AND DEDICATED EASEMENTS:
Grantee shall have the right to use the streets and dedicated easements of the
grantor for the construction, operation and maintenance of the cable system.
   A.   Grantee, at its own cost, shall have the right pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter to construct, erect, suspend, install, renew,
maintain and otherwise own and operate throughout the streets and dedicated
easements of the grantor, as now laid out or dedicated and all extensions
thereof and additions thereto in the grantor, the cable system, either
separately or in conjunction with any public utility operating within the
grantor. The permit shall further include the right, privilege, easement and
authority to construct, erect, suspend, install, lay, renew, repair, maintain
and operate such poles, wires, cable, underground conduits, manholes, ducts,
trenches, fixtures, appliances and appurtenances for the purpose of
distribution to inhabitants within the jurisdictional limits of the grantor.
Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the permit shall and does
hereby include the right to repair, replace and enlarge and extend the cable
system, provided that grantee shall utilize the facilities of utilities
whenever practicable.
   B.   Grantee shall have the right to remove, trim, cut, and keep clear of
the cable system, the trees in and along the streets and dedicated easements of
the grantor, provided that in the exercise of such right, the grantee shall not
cut, remove, trim, or otherwise injure such trees to any greater extent than is
necessary for the installation, maintenance, and use of the cable system.
   C.   Grantee in the exercise of any right granted to it by the permit shall,
at no cost to the grantor, promptly repair or replace any facility or service
of the grantor which grantee damages, including, but not limited to, any street
or dedicated easement or sewer, electric facility, water main, fire alarm,
police communication or traffic control. (Ord. 2004-15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-6: MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEM:
   A.   Grantee shall at all times employ ordinary care in the maintenance and
operation of the cable system so as not to endanger the life, health, or
property of any citizen of the grantor or the property of the grantor. The
cable system shall at all times be kept in good repair and in a safe and
acceptable condition.
   B.   Grantee shall install and maintain the cable system so as not to
interfere with the equipment of any utility of the grantor or any other entity
lawfully and rightfully using the streets and dedicated easements of the
grantor.
   C.   All conductors, cables, towers, poles and other components of the cable
system shall be located and constructed by grantee so as to reasonably minimize
interference with access by adjoining property owners to the streets and
dedicated easements. No pole or other fixtures of grantee placed in the streets
and dedicated easements shall interfere with the usual travel on such public
way. (Ord. 2004-15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-7: SERVICE:
   A.   Grantee shall provide to its subscribers broad categories of video
programming services.
   B.   Grantee shall extend the cable system to new developments within the
jurisdictional limits of the grantor, subject to a minimum density requirement
of forty (40) homes per cable mile.
   C.   Grantee shall provide basic service and one free outlet to each of the
following public facilities located within one hundred twenty five feet (125')
of existing service lines of the grantee and within the jurisdictional limits
of the grantor: city hall, each fire station and police station, public
libraries and schools. No monthly service fee shall be charged for such outlet.
Grantee shall provide basic service to new construction hereafter for similar
public facilities; provided they are within one hundred twenty five feet (125')
of the existing service lines of grantee. (Ord. 2004-15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-8: INSURANCE/INDEMNITY:
   A.   From and after the effective date hereof, grantee shall maintain in
full force and effect at all times for the full term of the permit, at the
expense of the grantee, a comprehensive general liability insurance policy,
written by a company authorized to do business in the state, protecting against
liability for loss or bodily injury and property damage occasioned by the
installation, removal, maintenance or operation of the cable system by grantee
in the following minimum amounts:
      1.   One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for property damage in any one
occurrence.
      2.   One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and two million
dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate for general liability insurance.
      3.   Workers' compensation coverage in accordance with state law.
   B.   The grantor and its officials and employees shall be named as
additional insureds on said policy. The grantor shall be notified by the
insurance company at least thirty (30) days prior to the expiration or
cancellation of such insurance policy or policies.
   C.   Grantee hereby agrees to indemnify and hold the grantor, including its
agents and employees, harmless from any claims or damages resulting from the
actions of grantee in constructing, operating or maintaining the cable system.
Grantor agrees to give the grantee written notice of its obligation to
indemnify grantor within ten (10) days of receipt of a claim or action pursuant
to this section. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the grantee shall not be
obligated to indemnify grantor for any damages, liability or claims resulting
from the wilful misconduct or negligence of grantor or for the grantor's use of
the cable system. (Ord. 2004-15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-9: CANCELLATION AND EXPIRATION:
   A.   Unless earlier terminated in accordance with this chapter, the permit
shall expire fifteen (15) years after the effective date hereof.
   B.   Prior to revocation or termination of the permit, the city council
shall give written notice to the grantee of its intent to revoke the permit on
the basis of a pattern of noncompliance by the grantee, including one or more
instances of substantial noncompliance with a material provision of the permit.
The notice shall set forth the exact nature of the noncompliance. The grantee
shall have sixty (60) days from such notice to either object in writing and to
state its reasons for such objection and provide any explanation or to cure the
alleged noncompliance. If the city council has not received a satisfactory
response from grantee, it may then seek to revoke the permit at a public
hearing. The grantee shall be given at least thirty (30) days' prior written
notice of such public hearing, specifying the time and place of such hearing
and stating its intent to revoke the permit.
   C.   At the hearing, the grantor shall give the grantee an opportunity to
state its position on the matter, present evidence and question witnesses,
after which it shall determine whether or not the permit shall be revoked. The
public hearing shall be on the record and a written transcript shall be made
available to the grantee within ten (10) business days. The grantee may appeal
such determination to an appropriate court, which shall have the power to
review the decision of the grantor de novo.
   D.   Upon termination of the permit, grantee agrees to remove the cable
system from the streets and dedicated easements of the grantor. (Ord. 2004-15,
9-9-2004)
7-7-10: ENFORCEMENT OF TERMS AND CONDITIONS:
Either the grantor or grantee may institute proceedings in a court of competent
jurisdiction to enforce the terns and conditions of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-
15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-11: EQUAL PROTECTION:
The grantor shall not authorize or permit any person providing video
programming services and/or cable services to enter into any part of the
grantor's streets on terms or conditions more favorable or less burdensome to
such persons than those applied to the grantee pursuant to this permit, in
order that one operator not be granted an unfair competitive advantage over
another, and to provide all parties equal protection under the law. (Ord. 2004-
15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-12: NOTICES, MISCELLANEOUS:
   A.   Every notice served upon the grantor shall be delivered or sent by
certified mail, return receipt requested, to:
City of McLoud
Attn: City Clerk
107 N. Main
P.O. Box 300
McLoud, Oklahoma 74851
and every notice served upon grantee shall be delivered or sent by certified
mail, return receipt requested, to:
Charter Communications
Attn: General Manager
707 W. Saratoga
Shawnee, Oklahoma 74801
With a copy to:
Charter Communications
Attn: Corporate Government Affairs
12405 Powerscourt Drive, 4th Floor
St. Louis, Missouri 63131
   B.   All provisions of this chapter shall apply to the respective parties,
their successors and assigns.
   C.   If any particular section of this chapter shall be held invalid, the
remaining provisions and their application shall not be affected thereby. (Ord.
2004-15, 9-9-2004)
7-7-13: PAYMENT TO CITY:
Grantee shall pay to the grantor, within ninety (90) days after each calendar
year, an amount equal to three percent (3%) of the gross revenues for such
calendar year. The grantor shall have the right to review the previous year's
books of the grantee to ensure proper payment of the fees payable hereunder.
(Ord. 2004-15, 9-9-2004)
CHAPTER 8
BOATING AND WATER SAFETY CODE
SECTION:
7-8-1: Citation
7-8-2: Code Controlling
7-8-3: Adoption Of Oklahoma Boating Safety Act
7-8-4: Application Of Regulations
7-8-5: Obedience To The Boating And Water Safety Code
7-8-6: Penalty
7-8-1: CITATION:
This chapter and all amendments hereto may be cited or referred to as the
BOATING AND WATER SAFETY CODE, CITY OF MCLOUD, and may so appear upon all
official documents, records or instruments. (Ord. 2010-12, 6-24-2010)
7-8-2: CODE CONTROLLING:
Except as specifically provided by law as set forth in this chapter, the
boating and water safety code shall be applicable in all areas of Wes Watkins
Lake within the city limits of McLoud. (Ord. 2010-12, 6-24-2010)
7-8-3: ADOPTION OF OKLAHOMA BOATING SAFETY ACT:
   A.   Boating Safety Act Adopted: The provisions of the Oklahoma boating
safety act, 63 Oklahoma Statutes section 4200 et seq., and the rules and
regulations adopted pursuant thereto are hereby adopted and incorporated herein
by reference, and are enforceable by the city within the city limits as fully
as if set out at length herein.
   B.   Definitions Adopted: The provisions and definitions contained in 63
Oklahoma Statutes section 4200 are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by
reference, applicable to control of water and boating safety and to this
chapter. (Ord. 2010-12, 6-24-2010)
7-8-4: APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS:
The police department and any authorized rangers or employees of the city may
enforce this chapter and ordinances governing and regulating the operation and
use of watercraft within the limits of the city. (Ord. 2010-12, 6-24-2010)
7-8-5: OBEDIENCE TO THE BOATING AND WATER SAFETY CODE:
   A.   Committing Unlawful Act: It is an offense against the city for any
person to do any act forbidden or to fail to perform any act required by this
chapter.
   B.   Parental Responsibility: It is an offense against the city for the
parent of any child or for the guardian of any ward to authorize or knowingly
permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Permitting Violations: It is an offense for any person to authorize or
knowingly to permit any boat or watercraft registered in his or her name to be
operated, used or occupied in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 2010-12, 6-24-2010)
7-8-6: PENALTY:
Every person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of
an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2010-12, 6-24-2010)
TITLE 8
UTILITIES
CHAPTER 1
UTILITIES GENERALLY
SECTION:
8-1-1: Application For Utility Service
8-1-2: Utility Fees And Billings In General
8-1-3: Payment Of Bills; Adjustments For Undue Hardship
8-1-4: Failure To Pay Bills; Service Disconnection
8-1-1: APPLICATION FOR UTILITY SERVICE:
   A.   Contract; Fees And Deposits: Every person, firm or corporation desiring
to have their premises connected to any of the City’s utilities, water, sewer,
or trash collection, shall make application and sign a contract upon a printed
form to be furnished for that purpose, and shall pay the regular fees and
deposits for installation of the service.
   B.   No utility account may be established, for a new structure, or an
existing structure after a change in use or occupancy, unless such structure
shall have first been inspected by the City of McLoud or its designated
representative to verify compliance with the building and safety codes of the
City of McLoud
   C.   Return Of Deposit: The deposit shall be returned to the user when the
contract is terminated, providing all bills for services are paid in full.
(Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003; amd. Ord. 2023-06, 3-23-2023)
8-1-2: UTILITY FEES AND BILLINGS IN GENERAL:
   A.   Rendition Of Bills:
      1.   All fees and charges in connection with any customer's use of the
sanitary sewer system, the water facility system, or the operation of the
City's collection and disposal of refuse and garbage are billed in accordance
with applicable rates set as provided in subsection B of this section.
      2.   All fees and charges owing for any of these utility services shall
be billed on one monthly bill submitted to the customer each month. (Ord. 2003-
07, 8-28-2003)
      3.   Meters are read on the 15th/16th day of the month (or the first
business day thereafter) with exceptions made for inclement weather or other
cause as deemed necessary by the City. Billing for the prior period shall be
mailed on or about the 1st business day of the following month. (Ord. 2018-06,
6-28-2018)
   B.   Charges Set By City Council:
      1.   The City Council shall establish rates, charges, deposits, and fees
for utility services by ordinance, motion, or resolution, as the case may be. A
copy of the current rates and charges shall be available in the City Clerk's
Office. (Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003; amd. Ord. 2013-10, 6-27-2013)
      2.   In addition to such other fees as are charged for sewer, water and
solid waste there shall be charged to each resident or owner receiving sewer,
water or solid waste services the sum of five dollars ($5.00) or such greater
or lesser sum as shall be established by resolution of the City Council. Such
fees shall be segregated within the general accounts of the City of McLoud/
McLoud Public Works Authority for the sole purpose of expansion, replacement
and repairs to the existing water and sewer systems of the City, including
replacement of water meters, water wells and storage facilities, repairs and
extensions to the sewer and water system or the payment or retirement of any
debt used to finance such expansion, repair and/or replacement. (Ord. 2013-10,
6-27-2013)
8-1-3: PAYMENT OF BILLS; ADJUSTMENTS FOR UNDUE HARDSHIP:
   A.   Monthly Billings; Payment Required: All bills for utility services
shall be rendered monthly, and as soon after the meter reading date as
practical. Reasonable care will be exercised for delivery of utility bills.
Failure to receive such bills shall not relieve the consumer from payment of
bills within the prescribed period, nor exempt him from the responsibility
imposed for delinquency of accounts.
   B.   Time Of Payment; Delinquencies; Service Disconnection: All charges for
utility services shall be due and payable at the City offices, at the time and
date indicated on the bill. The City will accept partial payments; however, all
accounts not paid in full will become delinquent. Delinquent accounts will be
subject to disconnection. Water service will be reestablished after the bill is
paid in full.
   C.   Adjustments For Undue Hardship: Authorized agents of the City are
empowered from time to time to make adjustments in the charges for utility
services and in the bills rendered to customers, when an investigation by any
person reveals that: 1) the charges are excessive due to legitimate reasons or
causes; 2) in the judgment of the authorized agent, the full charge would place
an undue and unfair hardship on the consumer; or 3) for any other reason the
agent deems appropriate. (Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003)
8-1-4: FAILURE TO PAY BILLS; SERVICE DISCONNECTION:
   A.   Actions And Penalties For Nonpayment: Upon failure of any customer to
pay any part of a utility bill for any utility services by the due date on the
bill, the following actions and penalties may result: (Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003)
      1.   A late payment penalty, as established by the City Council by motion
or resolution, shall be added to each utility bill not paid in full on or
before the 15th day of the month or the first business day thereafter if the
15th is not a business day. The late payment penalty shall be added by four
thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M. the date the payment is due.
      2.   Full payment of the utility bill must be made on or before the 25th
day of the month, or the next business day if the 25th is not a business day.
Upon failure to make the payment in full or make payment arrangements in
writing, on or before the due date, the City, after mailing or posting notice
of intent to disconnect or discontinue utility services, may disconnect or
discontinue utility service. Customers may request, in writing, a hearing
before the City Manager, regarding the termination or discontinuance of
service. (Ord. 2018-06, 6-28-2018)
      3.   The authorized agents of the City may discontinue furnishing water
to any customer refusing or neglecting to pay all or any part of a utility
bill, upon providing written notice to the customer of the intent of the City
to disconnect water service.
   B.   Reconnection Or Reestablishment Of Service: If any utility service is
discontinued or disconnected pursuant to this section, the City, or its agents,
shall not reconnect or reestablish the service until the full amount of any
outstanding utility service bill is paid, plus any applicable charges or
expenses incurred in reconnecting or reestablishing the service. Payments must
be made with cash, cashier's check, or money order. No personal checks will be
accepted after the twenty second of the month.
   C.   Added Charge For Disconnecting Service: If an occupant has been
notified that utility service will be discontinued and City personnel have been
dispatched to disconnect service, there shall be an additional fee added to the
bill. All bills, penalties, and fees collected, as hereinabove specified, shall
be paid to the Utility Clerk. Nothing herein shall be construed as preventing
the City from instituting suit for the recovery of any delinquent accounts.
   D.   Payment Of Entire Utility Bill Required: The City Clerk may not accept
payment of a water bill without payment of the sewer service charge; nor shall
the Clerk accept payment of a sewer bill without payment of the water bill. The
failure to pay any utility bill in accordance with subsections A and B of this
section shall be grounds for discontinuing any or all of the utility services
furnished to the customer whose bill is delinquent. (Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003)
   E.   Transfer Fee: Every person, firm or corporation desiring to have their
utility service transferred to another location shall submit a request for
transfer upon a printed form to be furnished for that purpose, and shall pay
the transfer fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for that service. (Ord. 2010-
06, 11-24-2009)
CHAPTER 2
WATER AND SEWER SYSTEMS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Lease Of Systems
8-2-2: Mandatory Connection To City Water And/Or Sewer
8-2-3: Separate Service
8-2-4: Right Reserved To Interrupt Water Service
8-2-5: Damaging Equipment
8-2-6: Tampering With Meters Unlawful
8-2-1: LEASE OF SYSTEMS:
   A.   Lease To Public Works Authority: The city has leased the operation of
its water and sewer systems to the McLoud public works authority, including
setting rates for use of the systems and all regulations governing them. For a
copy of current rates and rules, see the minutes of the McLoud public works
authority.
   B.   Rates And Rules Adopted By Reference: The rates and rules of the McLoud
public works authority are adopted and incorporated herein by reference; fully
applicable, as if set out at length herein. Violations are punishable as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003)
8-2-2: MANDATORY CONNECTION TO CITY WATER AND/OR SEWER:
   A.   Conditions For Connection: Each occupied residence and each occupied
business or commercial building in the city shall connect to the city water
and/or sewer system when such city water service or sewer system is available
within one hundred feet (100') or less of the property line of the residence or
business to be served or within three hundred feet (300') of the improvements
to be served. (Ord. 2010-07, 2-25-2010)
   B.   Exceptions: Occupied residences or business or commercial buildings
having approved water supply and/or sewer or septic systems, as of the
effective date hereof, shall not be required to connect to the city water and/
or sewer system. This exception shall, however, apply to such residences,
business or commercial buildings in the event the water supply and/or sewer or
septic system shall cease to be approved by any governmental authority having
regulatory authority. (Ord. 2013-09, 6-27-2013)
   C.   Penalty For Failure To Connect: Any person, firm, corporation, or
entity violating any provision of this section shall, upon conviction thereof,
be liable for a fine of not to exceed twenty dollars ($20.00). Each day that
any violation of any provision of this section is allowed to exist shall be,
and constitute, a separate offense. (Ord. 2010-07, 2-25-2010)
8-2-3: SEPARATE SERVICE:
Every separate premises supplied must have its own separate service connection
with the mains or lines, and the premises so supplied shall not be allowed to
supply water or sewer to any other premises. (Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003)
8-2-4: RIGHT RESERVED TO INTERRUPT WATER SERVICE:
The city reserves the right to shut off the supply of water, without notice,
for repairs, extensions, nonpayment of rates, or for any other reason; and no
liability shall attach therefrom. (Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003)
8-2-5: DAMAGING EQUIPMENT:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to destroy or injure any water
pipe, hydrant, faucet, pole, or other sewer or water equipment erected or
placed by or belonging to the city. (Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003)
8-2-6: TAMPERING WITH METERS UNLAWFUL:
The tampering with water meters or meter boxes of the city, the placing of any
bypass connection on or around the meters, or the use of any other device
tending to interfere with the proper registration of same, is unlawful. The
name that appears on the water billing will be held liable for any illegal
tampering with water meters. (Ord. 2003-07, 8-28-2003)
CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE AND REFUSE COLLECTION
SECTION:
8-3-1: Purpose
8-3-2: Definitions
8-3-3: Collection And Disposal Rates
8-3-4: Reservation Of Right
8-3-5: Container Requirements
8-3-6: Enclosed Receptacles
8-3-7: Restricted Use Of Dumpsters
8-3-8: Penalty
8-3-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of this chapter to preserve and protect the health of the
public within the corporate limits of the city. (1987 Code § 17-201)
8-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in this section:
GARBAGE: Any accumulation of animal or vegetable matter, or both; including the
refuse matter from kitchens, pantries, dining rooms, or other parts of hotels,
restaurants, boarding houses, tenement houses, dwelling houses, market houses,
public institutions, private hospitals, all animal refuse from slaughterhouses,
all animal matter or refuse matter from butcher shops, the refuse animal matter
from fish stores, or other businesses or occupations.
REFUSE: Ashes, cinders, paper, broken ware, discarded shoes and clothing, tin
cans or vessels, iron or other metallic vessels, or their parts or iron or
other metallic scraps, wooden or paper boxes, cartons or other parts and such
refuse as may be termed the natural accumulation of resident families. (1987
Code § 17-202)
8-3-3: COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL RATES:
The owner or occupant on any and all premises in the city shall pay a
collection rate for the collection of garbage and refuse as set by the city
council by motion or resolution. (1987 Code § 17-206)
8-3-4: RESERVATION OF RIGHT:
   A.   Collection: The city reserves to itself the right and privilege to
collect, remove and dispose of and to provide for the collection, removal and
disposal of all garbage, rubbish, refuse, waste, trash and unwholesome and
unsanitary matter within the city, either by contracting with some suitable
person(s) for the removal of such or by removing the garbage, rubbish, refuse,
waste, trash and unwholesome and unsanitary matter by city employees, at its
discretion, or by some combination thereof. (Ord. 2010-11, 5-27-2010)
   B.   Superintendent Of Sanitation Department: If the city does not elect to
enter into a contract for the collection and removal of garbage, refuse and
rubbish as contemplated in this chapter, the city manager shall designate an
appropriate department to enforce this chapter and all other sections of this
code and city ordinances relating to sanitation. The person in charge thereof
shall inspect the work of garbage and rubbish collection and observe premises
in general to see that all regulations which relate to the placing, keeping and
removing of garbage and rubbish are strictly enforced. This section shall not
take away any of the authority or lessen the duty of any other city officer to
enforce this chapter or any other section of this code or city ordinance
relating to sanitation. (Ord. 2010-09, 4-22-2010)
8-3-5: CONTAINER REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Standards For Receptacles; Placement Of Receptacles For Collection: All
owners, occupants or other persons in charge of any premises, including
residences, apartments, business and industrial establishments, hospitals,
educational institutions and all other establishments of any kind whatsoever in
the city, shall place all garbage in containers to be supplied by the
contractor for the city's pick up service, or otherwise approved by the city.
Commercial solid waste containers that are compatible with the loading
mechanisms of garbage trucks used by the city or its approved contractor(s) may
be used, upon approval by the department in charge thereof. Fifty five (55)
gallon drums and similar receptacles are specifically prohibited. (Ord. 2010-
11, 5-27-2010)
   B.   Containers: Containers shall be placed curbside at least three feet
(3') from any mailbox, gas meter, fire hydrant or any other utility equipment
or structure located above ground and within two feet (2') of the curb or road.
Placement of the containers in alleys is specifically prohibited. Containers
shall be removed from the road or curb and returned to the premises of the
owner within a reasonable time following trash collection, but not to exceed
twenty four (24) hours. The city manager may waive or modify such requirement
for residents with physical limitations or disabilities provided the containers
are placed so as not to impede traffic or create a hazard to others. (Ord.
2013-06, 5-23-2013)
   C.   Parking: No person shall park a vehicle, in such manner as to interfere
with the collection of solid waste between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00)
A.M. to five o'clock (5:00) P.M. along a road where garbage is to be picked up
that day. (Ord. 2010-09, 4-22-2010)
   D.   Sanitary Condition: It is the duty of the owner of the containers to
keep them clean at any and all times and to maintain them in a sanitary
condition. (1987 Code § 17-203)
   E.   Address: Any occupant or resident of premises that regularly receives
mail at other than the physical address of the premises, shall, upon request,
furnish such mailing address to the city for billing purposes. (Ord. 2010-11,
5-27-2010)
8-3-6: ENCLOSED RECEPTACLES:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to deposit for collection on any
street, alley, or parking of the city or on any private property, any refuse,
rubbish or trash which is not in containers required herein. Each day such is
permitted to remain loose in an alley, street or parking shall constitute a
separate offense. (1987 Code § 17-205)
8-3-7: RESTRICTED USE OF DUMPSTERS 1 :
It is unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person, firm or corporation, other
than the authorized user, to deposit garbage or refuse for collection in any
commercial dumpster located within the city limits. (1987 Code § 17-207)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  4-3-9 of this code.
8-3-8: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or who fails to provide
the necessary garbage receptacles as herein required shall be deemed guilty of
a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. Each day's continuance or failure to
comply herewith shall constitute a separate and distinct offense for each day.
(1987 Code § 17-208)
TITLE 9
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODE AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Building Code Adopted; Amendments
9-1-2: Building Official
9-1-3: Permits; Fee
9-1-4: Fire Limits
9-1-5: Penalties
9-1-6: Fences
9-1-1: BUILDING CODE ADOPTED; AMENDMENTS:
   A.   A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the Office
of the City Clerk of the City of McLoud, being marked and designated as the
2012 International Building Code, and all future modifications or amendments
thereto, is hereby adopted as the Building Code of the City of McLoud in the
State of Oklahoma; for the control of building and structures as herein
provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties,
conditions and terms of said Building Code are hereby referred to, adopted, and
made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions,
insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection B of this
section.
   B.   The following sections are hereby revised:
Section 101.1 Insert: city of McLoud
Section 1612.3 Insert: city of McLoud
(Ord. 2013-17, 11-21-2013)
9-1-2: BUILDING OFFICIAL:
   A.   Powers And Duties: The building official of the City shall have the
powers and duties prescribed for the "building official" by the City's Building
Code; provided, that his powers and duties may be exercised by his authorized
representatives under his supervision and control.
   B.   Act As Inspectors: The term "building inspector", whenever used in the
ordinances of the City, means the building official. The terms "electrical
inspector", "plumbing inspector", and "gas inspector", wherever used in the
ordinances of the City, also each refer to and mean the building official,
unless a separate electrical inspector, plumbing inspector, or gas inspector is
appointed. (1987 Code § 5-104)
9-1-3: PERMITS; FEE:
   A.   Permits Required: No building or other structure shall be built,
enlarged, altered, demolished, moved or removed without a building permit as
required by the City Building Code. Prior to commencing any earth disturbing
activity, temporary erosion control measures shall be installed, and an earth
change permit shall be acquired from the City Clerk.
   B.   Applications For Permits: A person desiring a building or earth change
permit shall submit an application and required fees therefor to the City
Clerk. The applicant shall submit with the application and provide such
information as shall reasonably be required by the Clerk to determine whether
the permit shall be issued in conformance to the requirements of the codes of
the City of McLoud. (Ord. 2019-01, 1-24-2019)
   C.   Permit Issuance; Payment Of Fees:
      1.   If the application is in accordance with the requirements of the
ordinances and laws, the Clerk shall issue the permit upon the payment by the
applicant of a building permit fee which may be set by motion or resolution of
the City Council. A current copy of the fee schedule shall be kept in the
Office of the City Clerk.
      2.   Nonprofit religious corporations and churches or religious societies
organized pursuant to 18 Oklahoma Statutes section 562 shall pay a percent of
the building permit fee as determined by motion or resolution of the City
Council. (1987 Code § 5-105)
9-1-4: FIRE LIMITS:
The fire limits shall include all that part of the incorporated City lying
within the City limits. (1987 Code § 5-107)
9-1-5: PENALTIES:
   A.   Penalty Imposed: Any person, firm or corporation who shall engage in
any business, trade or vocation for which a license, permit, or certificate of
registration is required by this title, without having a valid license, permit,
or certificate of registration as required, or who shall fail to do anything
required by this title or by any Code adopted by this title, or who shall
otherwise violate any provision of the chapters in this title or of any Code
adopted by this title, or who shall violate any lawful regulation or order made
by any of the officers provided for in this title, shall be guilty of an
offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1987 Code § 5-1101)
   B.   Relief In Courts: No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this title
shall interfere with the right of the City also to apply to the proper courts
of the State for a mandamus, an injunction or other appropriate action against
such person, firm or corporation. (1987 Code § 5-1102)
9-1-6: FENCES:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided in the Code or building regulations of the
City of McLoud, all fences in any area zoned as residential shall conform to
the following standards:
      1.   Fences shall be constructed of suitable materials and maintained in
good working condition, and may be chain link, wooden or synthetic stockade,
wrought iron, wooden or synthetic picket, stone or brick masonry. Fences shall
include a top rail when that is customary, such as with chain link. Fences may
be of other material and design if approved in advance by Code Enforcement.
      2.   The following materials or designs are prohibited: T-post, barbed
wire, razor wire, hog wire, chicken wire or similar materials. Fences designed
or constructed to create the impression or appearance of a compound are
prohibited.
      3.   Fences shall not be over eight feet (8') high on the rear or sides
of any lot(s), and shall not be over five feet (5') high on any portion of the
fence extending beyond the front of the residence.
   B.   This prohibition shall not apply to any fence in existence upon the
effective date of this section, except in the event of a sale or transfer.
Nothing herein shall be considered to restrict or limit the authority of the
City to require the removal or repair of existing fences when authorized by
other sections of the Code or building regulations, or when such fence is
determined to be a nuisance or hazard to the public health and safety.
   C.   Any person who violates the provisions of subsection A of this section
shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of two
hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 2017-07, 7-27-2017)

9-2-1: PLUMBING CODE ADOPTED:

city clerk of the city of McLoud, being marked and designated as the

the code of the city of McLoud for regulating the design, construction, quality
of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation,
replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of plumbing systems in the city of
McLoud and providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees

of such international plumbing code, 2012 edition, published by the

hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this
section. (Ord. 2013-19, 11-21-2013)

Section 101.1 Insert: city of McLoud
   (Ord. 2013-19, 11-21-2013)
9-2-3: PLUMBERS; REGISTRATION AND FEES:
   A.   Definitions Pursuant To Statute: The phrases and words "journeyman
plumber", "plumber's apprentice", "plumbing contractor", and "plumbing", when
used in the ordinances, regulations and other official acts and communications
of the city, shall have the meanings respectively prescribed for them by 50
Oklahoma Statutes section 1003, the state plumbing license law, unless the
context clearly indicates a different meaning.
   B.   Certificate Of Registration Required: It is unlawful for any person to
engage in the business, trade, or occupation of a plumbing contractor
(otherwise known as a master plumber), or of a journeyman plumber, or of a
plumber's apprentice, in the city unless he is registered with the city and has
a current and valid certificate of registration issued by the city.
   C.   State Licenses Required: Only persons who have current and valid
licenses as plumbing contractors or as journeyman plumbers issued by the
construction industries board, as provided by the state plumbing license law,
may register as such with the city. Only persons who have current and valid
certificates of registration as plumber's apprentices issued by the
construction industries board, as provided by the law, may register as such
with the city.
   D.   Issuance; Term Of Registration:
      1.   Applicants for certificates of registration, as plumbing contractor
or journeyman plumber, after complying with the laws of the state and with the
city code, and after payment of the registration fee, shall be registered by
the city clerk.
      2.   The registration shall expire on June 30 each year, but may be
renewed from year to year. Plumbing contractors desiring to renew their
registration shall furnish the same evidence of compliance with state licensing
laws.
   E.   Expiration Of Registration: All plumbing contractors' registrations not
renewed within ninety (90) days after the date of expiration thereof shall be
canceled, and a new application for registration must be made and the fee for a
new registration paid.
   F.   Fee: The fee for registration and renewal of registration shall be as
set by the city council by motion or resolution.
   G.   Revocation Of Registration; Notice; Hearing: The city council, upon at
least ten (10) days' notice and adequate opportunity for a public hearing, may
revoke the city registration of any plumbing contractor or journeyman plumber
for violating any provisions of the ordinances or regulations of the city
relating to the installation of plumbing or for any other cause specified in
the state plumbing license law. (1987 Code § 5-203; amd. 2004 Code)
9-2-4: PLUMBING WORK; PERMIT AND INSPECTION:
   A.   Permit Required: Except as provided by the International Plumbing Code,
no plumbing work shall be undertaken without a permit issued by the City.
   B.   Fee Schedule; Payment:
      1.   The schedule of permit fees may be set forth by resolution or motion
of the city council. Such payment will be made upon application.
      2.   Nonprofit religious corporations and churches or religious societies
organized pursuant to 18 Oklahoma Statutes section 562 shall pay a percent of
the plumbing permit fee as determined by motion or resolution of the city
council.
   C.   Inspection: Inspection of such work must conform to the guidelines set
forth in the city code. (1987 Code § 5-204; amd. Ord. 2023-07, 4-27-2023)
9-2-5: STREET EXCAVATIONS; PERMIT REQUIRED 1 :
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall dig or excavate within, along, through
or under any street, alley, sidewalk, or crossing or any other public place
within this city without first obtaining a permit to do so from the city clerk,
and no such permit shall be issued to persons other than those having been
licensed by the city for any such work to the effect that such person restore
or repair any and all damage to any street, alley, or sidewalk in as good
condition as the same was before any such work started.
   B.   Application For Permit: The application for such work shall be as
required by the city. (1987 Code § 5-205)

ELECTRICAL CODE

9-3-1: Electrical Equipment Defined

9-3-1: ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT DEFINED:
The term "electrical equipment", as used in this chapter, refers to electrical
conductors, metallic raceways, fittings, devices, fixtures, appliances,
apparatus, and any electrical material of any nature, kind, or description, to
be installed within or on any building or structure. (1987 Code § 5-301)
9-3-2: CONFORMITY WITH REGULATIONS, STANDARDS:
   A.   Electrical Code Adopted; Amendments:
      1.   A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the
office of the city clerk of the city of McLoud, being marked and designated as
the NEC 2011 NFPA 70: national electrical code international electrical code
series as published by the International Code Council including all amendments
or modifications thereto be and is hereby adopted as the code of the city of
McLoud for regulating the design, construction, quality of materials, erection,
installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition
to, use or maintenance of electrical systems in the city of McLoud and
providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each
and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of such in NEC
2011 NFPA 70: national electrical code international electrical code series, on
file in the office of the city of McLoud are hereby referred to, adopted and
made a part hereof as if fully set out in this subsection A.
      2.   The following sections are hereby revised:
Article 90.1A Insert: city of McLoud
(Ord. 2013-25, 11-21-2013)
   B.   Underwriters Laboratories, Inc.; Equipment: All electrical equipment
installed or used shall be in conformity with the provisions of this chapter,
the statutes of the state and any orders, rules and regulations issued by the
authority thereof, and with approved electrical standards for safety to persons
or to property. Unless by this chapter, by a statute of the state or any
orders, rules, or regulations issued by authority thereof, a specific type or
class of electrical equipment is disapproved for installation and use,
conformity with the standards of Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., shall be
prima facie evidence of conformity with approved standards for safety to
persons or to property. (1987 Code § 5-303)
9-3-3: SPECIAL RULINGS BY CITY COUNCIL:
The city council, by motion or resolution, shall have the authority to make
special rulings, when circumstances warrant, for the safeguarding of life and
property and the improvement of electrical installations. In all cases, persons
engaged in the installing of electrical equipment and holding an electrical
license must be notified by letter of these decisions. (1987 Code § 5-304)
9-3-4: ELECTRICAL INSTALLATIONS; PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required:
      1.   It is unlawful for any person to install or repair any electrical
wiring, fixtures, or apparatus in or on any building or structure in the
corporate limits of the city or make extensions to any existing electrical
installations without first securing a permit from the city.
      2.   Repair jobs in excess of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall also
require a permit.
   B.   Application For Permit: Applications for electrical permits shall be
made to the city clerk; and the applicant shall provide such plans,
specifications, and other data as may be reasonably required.
   C.   Payment Of Fees:
      1.   Established By City Council: The fee for an electrical permit shall
be as prescribed by motion or resolution passed by the city council.
      2.   Nonprofit Organizations: Nonprofit religious corporations and
churches or religious societies organized pursuant to 18 Oklahoma Statutes
section 562 shall pay a percent of the electrical permit fee as determined by
motion or resolution of the city council. (1987 Code § 5-305; amd. Ord. 2022-
06, 10-28-2021)
9-3-5: CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION; FEE:
   A.   Issuance Of Certificate; Conditions:
      1.   On the completion of the work covered by a permit in accordance with
all ordinances and laws, the city shall issue a certificate of inspection.
      2.   In the event an inspection is not made within five (5) working days
(Saturdays, Sundays and holidays excluded) after proper notification, the
builder or owner is authorized to proceed.
      3.   In this certificate, the city shall certify that the work is in
accordance with the rules governing the respective class to which it belongs,
as specified by this chapter.
      4.   Whenever a permit is issued for an addition to old work, which old
work does not conform to the rules as laid down in this chapter, upon the
satisfactory completion of the addition, the city shall issue a statement that
the new work complies with the rules.
   B.   Payment Of Inspection Fee:
      1.   The city council, by motion or resolution, may prescribe an
inspection fee to be paid to the city when electrical installations are
inspected by the electrical inspector.
      2.   Nonprofit religious corporations and churches or religious societies
organized pursuant to 18 Oklahoma Statutes section 562 shall pay a percent of
the electrical inspection fee as determined by motion or resolution of the city
council. (1987 Code § 5-306)
9-3-6: ELECTRICIANS; REGISTRATION AND BOND; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Certificate Required; Fee:
      1.   It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business, trade or
vocation of electrical contractor, journeyman electrician or apprentice
electrician without a certificate of registration as such secured from the
city.
      2.   The initial fee for a registration certificate, and any renewal, to
be paid to the city clerk, shall be as set by the city council.
      3.   A registration certificate must be renewed within ninety (90) days
following expiration of the certificate. After the expiration, an application
for a new certificate must be requested and the initial fee paid again.
      4.   No person may be registered with the city as contractor, journeyman
or apprentice unless he possesses a valid and current state license issued by
the state and pays the registration fee in such sum as set by the city council
by motion or resolution.
      5.   This certificate is not transferable to any other individual or
company.
   B.   Bond Requirements:
      1.   Every person receiving a certificate as an electrical contractor
shall file with the city clerk a bond in such sum as set by the city council,
executed with a surety company authorized to do business in the state.
      2.   The bond shall be conditioned that the principal will install all
electrical wiring, fixtures, appliances, and equipment in accordance with the
law and the ordinances and other regulations of the city relating to electrical
installations and in a workmanlike manner; that the principal shall, without
further cost to the person for whom the work was done, remedy any defective or
faulty work caused by poor workmanship or inferior or nonstandard material; and
that the city may be fully indemnified and held harmless from any and all
costs, expenses or damage resulting from the performance of his work as an
electrical contractor or apprentice electrician, as the case may be.
   C.   Exceptions:
      1.   For the installing of bell, telephone or signal systems not using
over twelve (12) volts, no registration or bond will be required. The
installation of same must comply with all other requirements of the ordinances
of the city.
   D.   Revocation Of Certificate; Hearing: After adequate opportunity for a
hearing, the city council may revoke the certificate of an electrical
contractor, an apprentice electrician, or a journeyman electrician. (1987 Code
§ 5-307; amd. Ord. 2023-05, 3-23-2023)
9-3-7: RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTION:
   A.   Right Of Entry: The building official or the duly authorized
representatives of the service company in the discharge of their duties, may
enter any building or premises at any reasonable time.
   B.   Refusal To Allow Entrance: The refusal of any owner, agent, or occupant
of such building to allow such entrance for inspection purposes shall be deemed
an offense and shall be punished as hereinafter provided. (1987 Code § 5-308)
9-3-8: PLUMBING COMPLETION REQUIRED BEFORE WIRING:
No wiring of any kind shall be installed in any structure until all plumbing
and pipe fittings are completely roughed in in order that the proper distances
from conductors to ground may be maintained. (1987 Code § 5-309)
9-3-9: INSPECTION AND REPAIR OF WIRING IN MOVED BUILDINGS:
   A.   Inspection Required: When a building or portion of a building
containing electrical wiring is moved from its foundation, the owner shall have
the electrical wiring and equipment in the building inspected and repaired
where necessary, providing proper grounding wires.
   B.   Wiring Permit; Request Inspection: The electrical contractor shall
obtain a wiring permit and request inspection. (1987 Code § 5-310)
9-3-10: PENALTY:
See section
9-1-5 of this title for penalty provisions. (2004 Code)
CHAPTER 4
FIRE CODE
SECTION:
9-4-1: Fire Code Adopted; Amendments
9-4-2: Enforcement
9-4-3: Limits For Storage Of Flammable Liquids, Explosives
9-4-4: Modifications
9-4-5: New Materials, Processes Or Occupancies; Permits
9-4-6: Appeals
9-4-7: Penalty
9-4-1: FIRE CODE ADOPTED; AMENDMENTS:
   A.   Code Adopted: A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file
in the office of the city clerk of the city of McLoud, being marked and
designated as the 2012 international fire code amending all amendments or
modifications thereof is hereby adopted as the code of the city of McLoud in
the state of Oklahoma; for regulating and controlling the limits for storage of
flammable liquids, explosives, modifications, new materials, processes or
occupancies, permits, appeals and penalties, in the city of McLoud city limits;
and providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and
each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of such
international fire code, 2012 edition, published by the International Code
Council on file in the office of the city of McLoud are hereby referred to,
adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this section. (Ord. 2013-
22, 11-21-2013)
   B.   Definition: Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the fire code
hereby adopted it shall be held to mean the city of McLoud. (1987 Code § 13-
103; amd. Ord. 2013-22, 11-21-2013)
   C.   Amendments: The following sections are hereby revised:
Section 101.1 Insert: city of McLoud
(Ord. 2013-22, 11-21-2013)
9-4-2: ENFORCEMENT:
The code hereby adopted shall be enforced by the chief of the fire department.
(1987 Code § 13-102)
9-4-3: LIMITS FOR STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS, EXPLOSIVES:
The limits referred to in the fire code, in which storage of flammable liquids
in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited, the limits referred to in which
bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, and the limits in which
storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are hereby established
as the city limits. (1987 Code § 13-104; amd. Ord. 2013-22, 11-21-2013)
9-4-4: MODIFICATIONS:
The chief of the fire department, with approval of the city council, shall have
power to modify any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted in his own
discretion or upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly
authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying
out the letter of the code; provided, that the spirit of the code shall be
observed, public safety secured and substantial justice done. The particulars
of such modifications when granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of
the fire department thereon shall be entered upon the records of the department
and for applications requesting change, a signed copy shall be furnished the
applicant. (1987 Code § 13-105)
9-4-5: NEW MATERIALS, PROCESSES OR OCCUPANCIES; PERMITS:
The chief of the fire department, and two (2) persons appointed by the city
council, shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving
affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or
occupancies which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in
the code. The chief of the fire department shall post such list in a
conspicuous place in his office, and distribute copies thereof to interested
persons. (1987 Code § 13-107)
9-4-6: APPEALS:
Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application or
refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions
of the code do not apply, or that the true intent and meaning of the code have
been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the
decision of the chief of the fire department to the city council within thirty
(30) days from the date of the decision appealed. (1987 Code § 13-106)
9-4-7: PENALTY 1 :
Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1987 Code § 13-108)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  9-1-5 of this title.

CHAPTER 7
SWIMMING POOL CODE
SECTION:
9-7-1: Swimming Pool Code Adopted
9-7-2: Fences And Gates Required
9-7-3: Penalty
9-7-1: SWIMMING POOL CODE ADOPTED:
The latest edition of the swimming pool code issued by the Building Officials
and Code Administrators International, Inc., is hereby adopted and not less
than one copy is now on file in the office of the city clerk. The code is
incorporated herein as though fully set forth herein, and the provisions
therein shall be controlling in the building, use, and maintenance of all
swimming pools within the area of the jurisdiction of the city. (1987 Code § 5-
701)
9-7-2: FENCES AND GATES REQUIRED:
   A.   Definition: The term "swimming pool", for the purposes of this chapter,
shall mean those tanks or other structures that are designed and maintained
primarily for swimming purposes and are so constructed that any portion thereof
has a depth of more than eighteen inches (18") below the surface of the ground;
or in the case of aboveground pools, such term shall mean any aboveground pool,
the top surface of the walls or deck of which are less than thirty six inches
(36") above the surface of the ground.
   B.   Fence: All private outdoor swimming pools shall be enclosed by a
substantial fence no less than forty eight inches (48") in height, so
constructed as to prevent, within reason, any person from gaining access
beneath or through the fence, and which has a similarly substantial gate of the
same height as the fence with facilities for locking the gate when the pool is
unguarded.
   C.   Gate: Whenever a gate is contained in any enclosure required under this
section, the gate shall be kept closed and locked at all times, except when
open for the purpose of ingress and egress. (1987 Code § 5-702)
9-7-3: PENALTY:
See section
9-1-5 of this title for penalty provisions. (2004 Code)

ACCESSIBILITY GUIDELINES FOR THE HANDICAPPED

9-8-1: MINIMUM GUIDELINES ADOPTED:
There is hereby adopted by reference for the purpose of establishing standards
ensuring that certain buildings and facilities are designed, constructed, or
altered so as to be readily accessible to, and usable by, physically
handicapped persons that certain set of standards known as part 1190 of title
36 of the code of federal regulations "Minimum Guidelines And Requirements For
Accessible Design", as adopted by the U.S. architectural and transportation
barriers compliance board for the purposes of implementing section 502(b)(7) of
the rehabilitation act of 1973 (29 USC 792(b)(7)) and as published at 47 FR
33862 on August 4, 1982, copies of which have been and now are filed in the
office of the city clerk; and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as
fully as if set out at length herein. From the date on which this section shall
take effect, the provisions of the standards shall govern all applicable
construction, alteration, equipment, use and occupancy, and location of
buildings and other structures and facilities within the corporate limits of
the city. (1987 Code § 5-801)
